Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Next-Generation Liquid Scintillator Detectors: Picosecond Timing and Quantum-Dot-Doped Scintillator
Award.AbstractNarration:
Even after more than a decade of great discoveries, the neutrino remains the most mysterious of the known fundamental particles. Basic questions about its properties endure; the most basic being whether the neutrino is its own antiparticle. If true, this Majorana nature of the neutrino would have profound implications to particle physics and cosmology, including an explanation for the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the universe. The only feasible experimental probes of the Majorana nature of the neutrino are experiments searching for the rare nuclear process, neutrinoless double-beta decay. The current set of experiments will probe the parameter space for Majorana neutrinos in the inverted mass hierarchy. The next generation of experiments will need to push into the normal mass hierarchy which requires an order of magnitude increase in mass and background suppression.

Liquid scintillator detectors scale well to large masses but advances are needed to obtain increased background suppression. This award will support a program of research that focusses on combining advances in photodetectors and the use of novel wavelength shifters in the form of nanocrystals called quantum dots to extract a directional signal from liquid scintillator detectors.

Broader impacts: Undergraduate research is critical for recruiting and retaining physics students. This award will be used to improve opportunities for transfer students. A seminar series on succeeding as a physics major will be developed and presented at UCLA. A modified version of the series will also be presented at Santa Monica College. Furthermore, this grant will sponsor an additional slot in UCLA's Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neutrinos remain the most mysterious particles of the standard model. Due to their large abundance, small changes in their properties can change the evolution of the universe. Unlocking their secrets requires very large detectors and the ability to accurately separate signal from background events. Due to the high intellectual merit of new paradigms of neutrino detection, the NuDot program was created to realize the first large-scale directional liquid scintillator detector. These detectors scale economically to large volumes and the ability to reconstruct the direction of events would be revolutionary, reducing backgrounds and facilitating the search for new physics.

The direction of particles can be reconstructed in a liquid scintillator by separating the early directional Cherenkov light from the more abundant scintillation light using the photon arrival time. We outlined the principle in JINST 9 (2014) P06012 and showed that with ~100 picosecond timing resolution this separation is possible. Furthermore,  the effect would be enhanced by liquid scintillators with absorption cutoffs at shorter wavelengths and photodetectors with enhanced detection efficiency at long wavelengths.

The design phase of the award was extended when we realized a smaller demonstration was required.  FlatDot is this smaller demonstration which uses 25 of the fast 2" photomultiplier tubes (PMTs) arranged in a 5 x 5 square.  We were able to test the performance of the PMTs and electronics,  develop the needed analysis techniques, and design the electron calibration source with its 3D printed collimator. The technical accomplishments enabled by FlatDot led to the first detection of Cherenkov light from 1-2MeV electrons in a liquid scintillator. These results were published in JINST 14 (2019) 02, P02005.

The "Dot" of NuDot stands for quantum dots. Due to their small size, these nanocrystals have the interesting optical property that their size determines their absorption and emission properties.  This ability to precisely tune the wavelength response of the scintillator with the nanocrystals is well-suited for enhancing the Cherenkov light relative to scintillation light. Furthermore, the nanocrystals can be made of isotopes of interest due to their unique nuclear properties. As part of this award, we continued to develop nanocrystal-doped liquid scintillators. The production of nanocrystals in the wavelength range of interest has not moved beyond the kg-scale. For this reason, we explored performing the synthesis ourselves. We found that the traditional core-shell synthesis is most likely too complex for our application. We then explored perovskite nanocrystals which have a very straight forward synthesis. We present the first characterization of perovskite-nanocrystal doped liquid scintillator in JINST 14 (2019) 11, P11024.

At the conclusion of this award, we have designed and constructed the NuDot detector. It consists of 152 new fast 2" PMTs and 59 slower refurbished 10" PMTs which image 1m3 of liquid scintillator in an acrylic vessel. It will now be used as a platform for testing new photodetectors, liquids scintillators and advanced algorithms to improve the extraction of the direction of low energy particles and prepare for the design of a kiloton-scale detector. Our first advanced algorithm a CNN-based classifier was recently published as Nucl.Instrum.Meth.A 947 (2019) 162604.

The broader impacts of this work are two-fold.  The project continues to be very multidisciplinary making uses of innovations in photodetector technology and chemistry.  The integration of these ideas into NuDot will find application beyond neutrino physics to a wide range of particle detection applications including those for national security. However, the focus of the broader impacts of this award was the training of undergraduates.  Over 20 undergraduates have taken part in the project including five who led the construction of the detector during the summer of 2019. Our undergraduates have gone on to graduate school in physics and materials science and have moved on to positions at companies that include programming for MathWorks and retrieving capsules for SpaceX.  The NuDot program based at MIT provided an unparalleled training opportunity and the success of our undergraduates is a product of this unique opportunity.
